utterances: Emily, we hope you're a proprietor of a bookstore in a not too distance future.
I hope so too.
Yes.
I'm just trying to keep connection with the community and make people realize that independent bookstores are more than just a store.
They are a place to meet and greet and make friends and hang out and build community.
Thanks very much.
Thank you.
And do you see the electronic services, the e-books and the Kindles, that sort of thing, are they going to be your primary competitor in the future?
I think you can't stand in the way of the freight train of change and it will become part of what we're about as the industry moves forward.
We certainly feel in our store that the print book will stay with us for a good long time and I hope forever.
Joyce Meskis, good luck to you too.
And thank you very much for dropping by to see us today.
Thank you.
Joyce Meskis, owner and founder of the Tattered Book Store, joined us here at Colorado Public Radio.
Tomorrow it's TALK OF THE NATION: SCIENCE FRIDAY.
Ira Flatow will be here with a talk with marine scientist Ellen Prager about some of the slimy and splendid creatures that live in our oceans.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Centennial, Colorado.

As you can imagine, Libyans in the United States have been watching events in their homeland closely over the past few weeks, and many report that it's difficult to stay in touch with family and friends.
The Libyan-American community is relatively small.
In fact, we don't really know how many Libyans live in the U.S.
because there aren't enough to be classified in the census.
But they have been organizing to get information in and out of Libya.
If that's you, call and tell us how you stay in touch, what you've been hearing.
Email us: talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our Website.
That's at npr.org.
Click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Hafed Al-Ghwell grew up in Libya and moved to the United States back in 1980.
He's working with the Libyan Outreach Group, which has been calling for international intervention in the current standoff.
And he's with us here in Studio 3A.
Nice to have you with us today.
Thank you.
And Sarah Abdurrahman joins from the studios in member station, WNYC, in New York.
She's a producer for WNYC's ""On the Media,"" which is distributed by NPR.
She joins us today, not in that role, but as a Libyan-American who's been working to get information out of her homeland.
And nice to have you with us today as well.
Thank you.
And, Hafed Al-Ghwell, let me begin with you.
What's it like -what was it like to grow up in Moammar Gadhafi's Libya?
Well, I was lucky enough and old enough to have a few years before Colonel Gadhafi, and it was a wonderful place to grow up as a child.
And I spent a few years after he took over, but before he became completely out of line and began his ideas and implementing his oppression in a sort of a very clear way.
So it was a wonderful place to actually grow up.
And once the colonel took office...
Yes.
...after a military coup - self-styled colonel.
He was the captain at that time...
Exactly.
...how - was he a daily presence in people's mind?
Absolutely.
They started slowly.
It wasn't - in the few years when I was there, he was still surrounded by the people who did the coup with him.
So he was sort of counterbalanced by their presence.
But you can see an increasing kind of radicalization and even daily life.
I mean, Libya was one of those nice, easy places where you had a lot of Western presence, a lot of ex-pats.
About 50 percent of the city were actually Americans and British and Italians.
And this is Tripoli?
Yes, because you had the largest, for example, American and - Air Force base outside the continent of the United States until about 1970 to '73.
Wheelus Air Force.
Exactly.
And then you have a lot of the oil companies, a lot of old Italian families who continue to stay in Libya after the occupation.
Tripolitania, in the old days, was an Italian dwelling.
It was a really beautiful place.
And I remember growing up on my street with many American kids who became lifelong friends and, you know, going to beach clubs and having a very wonderful time.
And then, slowly, you saw this radicalization that happened overnight and sort of the same kind of radical speeches coming from Egypt in the '50s and '60s, through Abdul Nasser.
And that became increasing, sort of trend, until about 1977, '78, when Gadhafi started to unilaterally make decisions and got rid of most of the people around him.
And he was no longer first among peers, but solely the president...
So when we spoke with Mr. Tsvangirai, he said a couple of things about youth.
One, that he does think that efforts like this one to mobilize global youth for democracy work and two, that Zimbabwean youth are critical in the election there.
So tell us a little bit more about what you at MTV and MTVU are doing to sort of connect global youth in the service of democracy.
Sure.
I think what we heard from Dispatch the band, who had formed a relationship with Morgan Tsvangirai, they talked about what they were doing in terms of trying to ensure fair elections.
And I think we've seen with our audience, whether it was years ago with the anti-apartheid movement in South Africa and much more recently our audience, college students in the U.S.
in particular, have been really some of the loudest voices on the issue of Darfur and helping to stop the genocide in Darfur.

And when we heard that he was interested in reaching out to young people - I think college students in general have been the real engine for a lot of the social change movements coming out of the U.S.

And the idea that while we are here in the midst of an election, and are encouraging our audience certainly to get involved, the idea that one that could change really the face of Zimbabwe is playing out and that there have been calls for free and fair elections.
And I think - we hope it will resonate with our audience and that they will see that putting pressure on Mbeki or the SADC can potentially have a positive impact.
Tell us a little bit about Dispatch, this band that made this connection.
They have a huge college following.
We had an intern that worked for us in New Orleans who introduced me to them several years ago.
And they have a rabid following.
And they did a sell-out concert at Madison Square Garden a few months ago - several months ago, that was sold out within 30 minutes so it speaks to the passion of their base.
But interestingly the money that they raised went to help the people in Zimbabwe and to help, specifically, ensure democracy in Zimbabwe.
And historically, music has been a powerful tool for activism and for social movements and it's inspiring when an opposition leader like Morgan Tsvangirai would reach out to a band like this.
Are you afraid that it seems partisan to work with an opposition leader but not with the sitting candidate for office?
You know, what we try to do with the spots - and you can see it at MTVU.com - is make the case that this is not about any one candidate.
It is about free and fair elections.
And I think that given that we are not about encouraging people to vote, because only Zimbabweans can vote, it is more about ensuring that there are opportunities for free and fair election.
You've done some really interesting, innovative and unexpected work in terms of how you feature international content.
You've had interactive games about Sudan.
How do those work and what do you think the target audience and the reaction has been?
You know, I think you are referring to our video game ""Darfur is Dying?
Right.

When we saw the audience, college students in particular, really passionate about saying never again, they'd looked at Rwanda, looked at other examples of recent genocide and they were speaking very loudly.
But we felt like we needed to reach beyond the activists and so much of our audience lives online.
That game has now been played millions and millions of times and has generated tens of thousands of letters to public officials to do more.
And I think the way this audience, young people today, they are reinventing activism online and I think you're going to see this continuous morphing of what activism means.
It's no longer just marching in the streets as it was when I was in college.
I think it is much more about taking over the digital space.
Steven, thanks.
Thank you.
Steven Friedman is the general manager and executive vice president of MTVU.
Back now with Day to Day, I'm Madeleine Brand.
The root of the current banking crisis housing is not looking any better.
Home prices took another dive in July according to the Case-Schiller index out today.
The west coast suffered some of steepest drops.
Marketplace's Janet Babin is here now.
And Janet, how low did prices fall?
Well, according to the Case-Schiller home price index, Madeleine which does a composite of 20 metro areas and then it does one of ten metro areas.
The 10-city index was down one tenth of one percent from a month earlier, so from June to July.
And the 20-city index was down nine tenths of a percent.
But year over year is where we see the drama, single family home prices plunged to record 16 point three percent this July compared to last July when you look at the index.
And which city saw the biggest drops?
Las Vegas is the worst, the weakest market according to the Case-Schiller index.
It's off more than 34 percent from the peak prices it saw in August of 2006.
Phoenix, San Diego, Los Angeles are also still hurting and surprisingly the Detroit markets are prices go up just a bit from June to July.
Markets in Atlanta, Boston, Dallas and Denver have had home price increases for the past three months or more.
So, it's looking like those markets may have begun to stabilize a bit.
But overall, home prices are still falling?
That's right.
And you know lower home prices, economists say are obviously tied to increases and foreclosures.
And we've seen you know, people can't pay their mortgages.
These foreclosures happen and then prices fall.
And given the situation with the rescue package yesterday, many economists believe housing prices are not going to turn around overall until at least next summer.
